topic_metadata.title: How to ignore right margin for a block?

posts.name: Carlos
posts.cooked: I would like that the lines of a block of code (I mean raw ```...``` text, not a Typst code block) continue over the margin instead of being wrapped to the next line, since they are just slightly larger than the lines of my document and reformatting the code would look bad. Thanks!
posts.raw: I would like that the lines of a block of code (I mean raw ` ```...``` ` text, not a Typst code block) continue over the margin instead of being wrapped to the next line, since they are just slightly larger than the lines of my document and reformatting the code would look bad. Thanks!

posts.name: Eric Biedert
posts.cooked:
This might depend on your specific document styles, but you could wrap the code block in another block with larger (or even infinite) width.

// (Just for making it more visible)
#show raw.where(block: true): set block(fill: silver, inset: 0.5em)

#block(width: calc.inf * 1pt)[
  ```py
  def this_is_very_long(param: 0):
    return "Hello World"
  ```
]

You could also do this with a show rule on raw.where(block: true), but then show-set rules on block may be applied multiple times, which may be unintended.

posts.cooked:
The correct way, if wrapping isn’t allowed, is to just reduce the font size for all or just a single code block.

#show raw.where(block: true): set text(0.9em)

posts.name: Ulrik
posts.cooked:
There’s the package marginalia for making margin notes, but it also has an element wideblock where you temporarily use a fuller width, taking from either left or right margin or both. And that could be a way to go about this too.

Also, a more principled(?) way of sizing an oversized block could be like this:

#block(width: 100% + 2cm)[]

Since then you only oversize it by a known amount (compare to your margin setting)
posts.raw:
There's the package marginalia for making margin notes, but it also has an element `wideblock` where you temporarily use a fuller width, taking from either left or right margin or both. And that could be a way to go about this too.


Also, a more principled(?) way of sizing an oversized block could be like this:

```typ
#block(width: 100% + 2cm)[]
```

Since then you only oversize it by a known amount (compare to your margin setting)

posts.cooked:
the way marginala does its wideblocks is simply

#pad(left: -left, right: -right, body)

and left & right are calculated from the configured margin widths (and on which side(s) the block is supposed to extend). You can easily hard-code these to whatever values fit your needs.

Using pad over block has the advantage of being able to extend easily to the left, and it is less susceptible to show rules messing it up.

cf. Padding Function – Typst Documentation
posts.raw:
the way marginala does its wideblocks is simply
```
#pad(left: -left, right: -right, body)
```
and `left` & `right` are calculated from the configured margin widths (and on which side(s) the block is supposed to extend). You can easily hard-code these to whatever values fit your needs.

Using `pad` over `block` has the advantage of being able to extend easily to the left, and it is less susceptible to show rules messing it up.

cf. https://typst.app/docs/reference/layout/pad/
